page.title: 05Transport - Historical
page.content: The earliest form of transport was on foot and there are a number of footpaths in Chertsey. They are most noticeable on open spaces such as Chertsey Meads.Towing paths are present along the banks of the River Thames and River Wey. This and the locks indicates that the river is navigable. The Wey Navigation reaches to Cox's Lock Mill and was used commercially a few years ago, but is now used for recreation. Some of these waterways are owned by the National Trust. Many street names in Chertsey originate from the old coaching routes from London, to Windsor and Guildford. Many of these used the pubs as hostelries.
